description: A music genre that originated in the African-American communities of New Orleans, Louisiana, in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with its roots in blues and ragtime. Jazz is characterized by swing and blue notes, complex chords, call and response vocals, polyrhythms, and improvisation.

subgenres.name: Swing
subgenres.description: Dominant in the 1930s and 1940s, Swing is characterized by a strong rhythm section, often with a 'swinging' eighth-note rhythm, and large ensembles (big bands).

subgenres.name: Bebop
subgenres.description: Developed in the 1940s, Bebop features fast tempos, complex chord progressions with rapid chord changes and numerous changes of key, instrumental virtuosity, and improvisation based on a combination of harmonic structure and melody.

subgenres.name: Cool Jazz
subgenres.description: Emerged in the late 1940s as a reaction to the frenetic pace of bebop. It is characterized by relaxed tempos and a lighter, more lyrical tone.

subgenres.name: Hard Bop
subgenres.description: An extension of bebop that incorporates influences from rhythm and blues, gospel music, and blues. It is characterized by a heavier, more driving feel.

subgenres.name: Fusion
subgenres.description: A genre that developed in the late 1960s by combining elements of jazz harmony and improvisation with rock music, funk, and R&B. Electric instruments are common.

subgenres.name: Smooth Jazz
subgenres.description: A commercially oriented crossover genre that became prominent in the 1980s. It emphasizes polish, melody, and a lighter, pop-influenced sound.
